data.title: Last name MCMANUS: origin and meaning
data.meta_description: Last Name : MCMANUS, Learn more about the geographical origin and the etymology of this last name
data.text:
Origin

McManus : Irish and Scottish: Anglicized form of Gaelic Mac Maghnuis or Mac Maghnusa a patronymic from Maghnus later Mánus a Gaelic form of the Scandinavian personal name Magnus made famous by St. Magnus of Orkney. As an Irish name this is found mainly in Roscommon and Fermanagh and is connected with the O'Connors or the Maguires; in Scotland it is connected with the Colquhouns.

Mackessy : from Ó Macasa ‘descendant of Macas’ a personal name of uncertain origin. Woulfe thinks it is a variant of Maghnus; see McManus.

Manis : 1: Scottish and Irish: variant of McManus. See also Magnus. This form of the surname is rare in Britain and Ireland and is found mainly in Northumberland England.2: Greek: from the personal name Manis a pet form of Manolis.3: Czech (Mániš): from a pet form of the personal name Emanuel.4: Czech (Maniš): derivative of German Mann ‘man’ (see Mann) or of a short form of a German personal name such as Manfred.5: French or Breton: unexplained. In France it is found mainly in Brittany (Finistère).6: Jewish (eastern Ashkenazic): from the Yiddish personal name Mane + the possessive suffix -s. As a male name this is a variant of Man 9. As a female name it is derived from a form of Mary (see Maria) borrowed from Slavic Christians.

Mannis : 1: Irish: shortened and altered form of McManus. There may have been confusion with Minnis.2: Jewish: variant of Manis.

Manous : Probably a shortened and altered form of Irish McManus.

Manus : Irish and Scottish: shortened form of McManus. This form of the surname is rare in Britain and Ireland.

Mayne : 1: English: variant of Main.2: English: habitational name from Broadmayne (Dorset). The placename derives from Proto-Welsh main ‘rock stone’.3: Irish (Tyrone): mainly of Norman origin (see Main 2) but in Fermanagh used sometimes to represent McManus.4: Americanized form of German Mehn.5: French: variant of Maine.

Maynes : 2: Irish: shortened Anglicized form of Gaelic Mac Maghnuis (see McManus).1: Scottish and English: variant of Mains.

McKessy : Irish: correctly Mackesy a reduced form of Ó Macasa ‘descendant of Macas (perhaps a variant of Maghnus; see McManus). The name has been mis-spelled as though it were a patronymic in Mac-.

McMains : Irish (northern): variant of McManus.

McManis : Irish: variant of McManus.

McManners : very likely a spelling in England of Irish McManus.

McMannis : Irish: variant of McManus.

McManns : from Mac Maghnuis see McManus.

McMannus : from Mac Maghnuis see McManus.

McMonies : from Mac Maghnuis or Mac Maghnusa see McManus.

McMonnies : from Mac Maghnuis or Mac Maghnusa see McManus.

Menzies : Scottish: variant of Manners in which the z was originally the Middle English letter ʒ (yogh) representing a sound similar to modern English y. The surname is pronounced Meenyus or Minyas in Scotland. The name was brought to Scotland in the 12th or 13th century by a family of Norman knights. It appears that the name was re-interpreted in Gaelic as containing a personal name and for variants ending -s there is a possibility of confusion with McManus. See also McMinn.

More
